title: How to go to high school in Japan - Quora

response.answer_text: How exciting (and scary)! Without knowing where in Japan your family is looking to go, there’s not a lot of advice any of us can offer about specific schooling options. That said, I’m going to be asking the impossible here, I know, but don’t worry about college. Don’t worry. Just do your best. If you go to a Japanese high school and your grades take an initial hit and then improve, that’s something incredibly positive you can address in your admissions essay. Any worthwhile college (or future employer) will look at your experience and say, “Wow, this student was thrown into an overwhelming situation, but kept cool, stuck with it, and got results. That’s the kind of person who will thrive here.” In a sea of kids with high GPAs and tons of extracurriculars, your application will stand out. If you go to an international school, don’t fret. There are many international schools (particularly near the big cities) that offer AP and IB courses, and even if yours ultimately doesn’t, you can still get to where you want to be. As an applicant from overseas, you will still stand out in a sea of applicants, especially if your standardized test scores and admissions essay display your potential. If you have a particular college you are interested in attending, once your future plans are hammered down a bit, research their admissions process and contact their admissions office if you anticipate any bumps in the road. Maybe something like, “Hello! I’m a junior interested in attending ABC University for your outstanding computer science program and I have a question about the application process. I am currently studying in Iroha City, Japan. I understand that your application requires sealed recommendations from two of my teachers; however, none of my teachers speak English. When it comes time to apply, may I submit my recommendations in Japanese? If not, may I have a translator open the letters to translate them for you?” If you ask a pertinent question, not only are you unique because you’re in Japan, you’re unique because you’re proactively planning and reaching out.

Why would you want to? The fact of the matter is, unless you were raised in Japan, you aren’t going to be able to handle a Japanese high school as a regular student, both linguistically and culturally. You simply aren’t going to understand what’s going on, and if you went to school in America, you are going to be bumping up against the walls of social appropriateness. Further, Japan is infamous as having one of the worst and most stressful education systems in the world, so why would you willingly inflict that on yourself? Japan isn’t the promise land. At best, it’s just another place to live, and at worst, it is a severely damaged country desperately in need of change to fix its many socio-economic problems. If your reasoning for wanting to come to Japan is because you think it’s like what you see in anime, you will be unpleasantly surprised.

I went to school in Japan when I was 16 and I didn't speak Japanese. My suggestion is that you go to an intensive language school for the first month or two before you start normal school. Within 3 months of being at school you language skills will improve dramatically. Within 6 months you'll be the family translator. Within 12 months you will have forgotten that you didn't speak Japanese. At least that was my experience.

You may not be going to a traditional high school, but an American school. They teach stuff to help you get adjusted to global life while maintaining your academical work plus some electives. This is one result I found of was this[1] I don’t know where in Japan you’ll be staying but you could take public transport and get there if you live far. Footnotes[1] The American School in Japan

If you have a valid visa to be in Japan, your district high school has to accept you. Nowadays, there are many foreign students in the Japanese school system. Of course you will have to learn Japanese without a doubt. If you go to an “international school”, there are good ones and bad ones but nearly all of them are very expensive. If you are going to an area with a large Indian minority population, I suggest you go to an Indian school. You will have to learn Japanese and possibly Hindi, but at least the schools will not clean out your parents' bank account, or so I have heard. Personally, I suggest going to a Japanese school, learn the language, and do well there.
